<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 279, 170, 291]]<|/det|> **PHYSICS** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 393, 311]]<|/det|> Paper 2 AS Level Structured Questions <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 341, 415, 352]]<|/det|> Candidates answer on the Question Paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 361, 367, 372]]<|/det|> No Additional Materials are required. <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 393, 388, 405]]<|/det|> # READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 420, 718, 432]]<|/det|> Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 325, 446]]<|/det|> Write in dark blue or black pen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 449, 503, 461]]<|/det|> You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 463, 504, 475]]<|/det|> Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 477, 380, 488]]<|/det|> DO **NOT** WRITE IN ANY BARCODES. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 503, 256, 514]]<|/det|> Answer **all** questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 529, 359, 540]]<|/det|> Electronic calculators may be used. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 543, 767, 555]]<|/det|> You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 569, 605, 580]]<|/det|> At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 583, 757, 595]]<|/det|> The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 124, 87]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 102, 666, 560]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{ms}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) \((\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{- 1})\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1u = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81\mathrm{ms}^{- 2}\)

\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]

\[f_{0} = \frac{f_{s}V}{\nu \pm \nu_{s}}\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 500, 595, 518]]<|/det|>
\[C = C_{1} + C_{2} + \ldots\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 636, 627, 654]]<|/det|>
\[1 / R = 1 / R_{1} + 1 / R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[434, 667, 518, 700]]<|/det|>
\[V_{H} = \frac{BI}{ntq}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 715, 560, 732]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\sin \omega t\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 747, 578, 765]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 775, 536, 810]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 408, 918, 440]]<|/det|>

<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
When monochromatic light is incident normally on a diffraction grating, the emergent light waves have been diffracted and are coherent.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 365, 136]]<|/det|>
Explain what is meant by

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 150, 181, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 151, 337, 167]]<|/det|>
diffracted waves,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 242, 180, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 243, 332, 259]]<|/det|>
coherent waves.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 335, 180, 354]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 335, 917, 352]]<|/det|>
Light consisting of only two wavelengths \(\lambda_{1}\) and \(\lambda_{2}\) is incident normally on a diffraction grating.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 365, 918, 413]]<|/det|>
The third order diffraction maximum of the light of wavelength \(\lambda_{1}\) and the fourth order diffraction maximum of the light of wavelength \(\lambda_{2}\) are at the same angle \(\theta\) to the direction of the incident light.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 425, 181, 444]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 425, 443, 457]]<|/det|>
Show that the ratio \(\frac{\lambda_2}{\lambda_1}\) is 0.75.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 459, 374, 476]]<|/det|>
Explain your working.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 613, 920, 632]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 644, 181, 663]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 645, 650, 661]]<|/det|>
The difference between the two wavelengths is \(170 \text{nm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 676, 410, 693]]<|/det|>
Determine wavelength \(\lambda_{1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 829, 918, 847]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\lambda_{1} =\) ............................................................ nm [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
